January 28, 1959 To whom it may concern On this date, January 28, 1959 I visited
Kaysam Corporation, Paterson, N.J. My former employer with the intent of
determining if they would be helpful to me in producing models of squeeze and
novelty toy ideas I have consented for products made of dry molded latex and/or
rotational or slush molded vinyl or the like. The basic ideas which I sketched
and described to both Carl Hotstein and Abe Duncan are hereby recorded primarily
because, after describing them to Duncan, he discussed my problem with Mr.
Ernest Gelles, president of the company without asking me if he should do so. He
told me that he had informed Gelles that I had some new ideas in squeeze toys
but did not go into the exact details. However, Carl Hotstein later remarked to
me that Abe Duncan cannot be trusted to maintain confidence. Basically the
designs evolve about a toy having a central body member or portion made out of a
dipped latex bellows, bellows or a rotational or slushed molded bellows portion.
A design is illustrated on page 7 consists of a toy (squeeze novelty, crib or
play toy) having a body with three portions, an upper body portion 12, a central
body portion 14 which is shaped like a bellows which extends at its lower end to
a lower body portion 16 or stand which may be molded integral with 14 or secured
thereto the tower end of 14 or of 16 may be secured to a Lenore Waldmeyer Jan
28, 1959 J.B. Silstein Sept. 5, 1959

upper body portion 12 hollow flexible molded plastic vinyl latex on
polyetheyline central body portion 14 bellows shape noisemaker lower body

August. 4. 1959 Record of Conception: The following product and packaging ideas
will be incorporated into patent application and will, in the coming months, be
delivered to Johnson and Johnson. I. Brush Covering - This was conceived a
number of years ago and the patent specification (first draft) worked out last
winter. It consists of several novel designs for ~~ pla ~~ covers for the
bristles or tufts of various types of brushes. The covers are preferably molded
of plastic and snap over or screw onto a formed section of the brush base
adjacent the bristle. II. Single Shot (liquid, cream, or powder) Dispensers It
has been conceived by me to provide a low cost dispenser or package for flowable
material for possibly for a single application of a liquid such as an
antiseptic, nose drops, face cream, ointment, burn salv oil (baby oil, ~~ it ~~
machine oil), medicine (spray), ~~ or the like ~~ powder or the like. These
dispensers are preferably made of plastic (from 2 heat sealed sheets (.001 to
.005 " thick) or thin walled tubing Conceived designs as follows

Nov 6, 1959 Concerning the above idea, an edge line or lines ~~ scann ~~ printed
on the sheet or sheets of plastic to be blow molded may be used for lateral
registration. The correction of the position of a photoelectric cell (error
signal derived in change in position when ~~ fo ~~ the motor driving the mount
for the cell laterally to maintain it in alignment with said line) may be used
to shift either the means guiding the sheets to align it with the mold or shift
the mold in a lateral position so that the printed matter on the sheet will be
exactly registered in the molded product. To protect the printed matter from
distortion when the sheet is blown into the mold, it may be provided between the
surface of one or both sheets. One method of providing it between surfaces is to
coat or laminate the same or other (sheet) material on the printed surface of
the sheet or to provide said printed illustration on the inside surface of the
sheet laminated thereto. Another method is to utilize a sheet of plastic in
white a photographic image has been reproduced and blow mold this material after
carefully heating to semi-molten state. Here are several article ideas which
together with the above, I intend to file patent application on. Imitation

January 26, 1960 Applications and improvements in TPR (GE. thermoplastic
recording) It is conceived to adapt the recently released T.P.R system to single
frame recording for so called "animated cartooning" or the like. The system as
announced by G.E. involves only the production of motion pictures and since the
section of the thermoplastic tape heated by induction (in the G.E. apparatus) is
well in advance of the section or length of the tape, it is not possible to
shoot individual frames with a time delay between each which is ~~ faster ~~
longer than the time it takes for the frame to pass thru modification to the
apparatus. Accordingly, a number of modifications to apparatus of this type are
hereby proposed to effect "cartooning" or single frame function. (1.) In the
first apparatus, automatic control means are provided for automatically drawing
the single exposed frame~~ pa ~~ of tape pat the induction heating means to form
the so called "ripple" image in the thermoplastic and when so formed (after

Nov. 30, 1949 Conception of Inventions: I. Toy Cow Which Can Be Milked: This toy

March 22-50 Conception of Device For Cooling Flash bulbs which are used for
internal photography (within the human body): The inventor has been informed
that present methods of photographing the inside of a person prior to operating
involved the use of a flash bulb which must be intense in light energy for a
least 1/25th of a second. With the present technique the patient may receive an
internal burn which may be painful and harmful to him. The author has conceived
of the following method of cooling said bulb after it has flashed for the
photograph. The inventor wished to discipate the heat generated (most of it) by
setting up an endothermic reaction immediately after the bulb has fired and
positioned so as to the discipate most of the heat before harm is done to the
patient. Sketch of invention (preliminary design sketch)

RECORD OF Conception of Invention: Title: MAgnetic Toy Derrick: & RELEASE
MECHANISM: Description: This toy relates to a derrick which utilizes a magnet
(permanent) to pick up toys or objects of a magnetically susceptible material
and means for releasing said objects without demagnetization. a temporary magnet
has been utilized before & in the art to accomplish this end but this requires a
source of electrical energy, usually a battery which may be worn out rapidly due
to the large current drain by the coil of the magnet. and the constant switching
on and off. Sketch:

In the drawing, a permanent magnet 1 is

6 to be catapulted. A suction cup 4 secured to the end of 1 is pressed against
the surface of 7 against the tension of spring 3. After a brief delay, the
spring 3 tension overcomes the suction cup holding force and the arm swings up
in the direction of the arrow A causing the ball 6 to be catapulted. Note: the
suction cup 4 may be replaced by a ~~ pie ~~ lump of tacky substance such as tar
or gum which holds down arm 1 until the tension of the spring over comes it. The

April 14  1950 Process For Finishing Aluminum with a Lustrous or Polished
Surface: The author proposes the following process for putting a highly
reflective and polished surface on aluminum and aluminum objects. It is the
desire to such a process where aluminum is to be used as a structure and as an
ornamental surface. At the time of this writing, no method has been developed
whereby aluminum may be chrome plated. The following technique may serve the
purpose and experiments will be conducted to ascertain if it may be successfully
and satisfactorily accomplished. ~~ Ch ~~ Step I  Chroming the aluminum surface
either by the present techniques or by the development of a technique whereby
the process may be accomplished at a lower temperature (solution temperature).
Step II  Polishing the chromised surface by: (a) Mechanical buffing (b) Acid
cleaning and polishing (c) Buffing or polishing the surface by using a fine
grained polishing or buffing compound suspended in a jet of high velocity steam
or air. This

would differ from sand blasting in that the working particles would be much
finer, they would be suspended in a liquid, fluid such as steam or other gas
which would be ejected through small nozzles at a very high velocity, impinging
on the surface and polishing it. Jerome Lemelson Apr. 14, 1950

Mar 21, 1957 Conception of devices for employing shock waves in process
manufacture, testing and control: The following devices were conceived about 5
months ago in the employment of shock waves to initiate or effect chemical and
physical change on materials or work in process. Definitions of terms SW= A
shock wave created in a fluid by spark discharge, chemical reaction (explosion),
or mechanical compression of the fluid. SWN  Shock wave created in a duct and
adapted to travel essentially normal to the walls of said duct along said duct
unless otherwise specified. DT  Duct in which one or a multiple of shock waves
are created in rapid succession or at any specified frequencies and travel from
one part of said duct to another part or end of said duct. Jerome H Lemelson Mar
21/57 J. M. B. Friediman 3/21/57

changed by said shock wave or waves. VE  An outlet valve from a duct or chamber
in which shock waves may be created or passed by, for the removal of a fluid or
flowable solid material or solid article admitted thereto to contact with or be
operated on by said shock waves. Other terms will be defined in the

Fig. 1 In fig. 1, two shock tubes DT-1 and DT2 are placed end to end in endwise
alignment so that the shockwaves SWN-1 and SWN2 created in each will approach
each other. By timing the formation of each shock in the upstream end of its
respective tube they may be made to appear at the working zone ZN (located at
the end of each tube) at essentially the same time. The fluid in zone ZN will
thus be compressed by the action of both waves converging thereon. If the waves
SWN1 and SWN2 are created by resonating effects in each tube (i.e.- if each tube
is the exhaust end of a pulse jet, free piston engine exhaust or any type of
tuned or J.H.L. 3/21/57 M.B. Friedman 3/21/57

as a result of said resonation) and if both tubes are operating in
synchronization with each other (i.e.- the intermittent or repetitive shocks ~~
waves arrive ~~ waves arrive at ZN at the same time) then both tubes will act
essentially as closed end or quarter wave tubes as the shocks will reflect off
each other upon impact ~~ and travel ~~ or intersecting and travel back the
tubes. Valves V-1 and VE are secured to the walls of the joined tubes DT-1 and
DT-2 adjacent said working zone ZN and are adapted to respectively admit and

April 11-19 1958 Record of Conception of Invention I. Designs for and methods
and making molds and molding apparatuses. S In the art of molding hollow bodies
out of liquid plastic materials such as vinyl plastisols and organisols, said
bodies are usually make by what is known as slush or rotational molding. ~~
wherein ~~ In these techniques, a measured quantity of liquid plastic is poured
into a closed mold thru an opening therein and the mold is rotated in one or
more directions as it passes thru a furnace. The walls of the mold become hot
while in the furnace and the plastic which contacts the entire surface thereof
as the mold rotates, cures to the shape of the exterior of the mold. After a
predetermined time ~~ when ~~ the mold emerges from the furnace and the excess
plastic, if any, is poured off. If no excess plastic is present, the hollow body
is ~~ may be ~~ pulled from the mold thereafter. The use of a furnace for
heating the mold has certain

### Page 5
disadvantages and shortcomings. In addition to the waste of a considerable
amount of heat not  a radiated to the molds, heat is lost where the molds enter
and leave the furnace. Furthermore a complex conveying system must be provided
for moving the molds into and out of the furnace which is costly and difficult
to maintain. Accordingly, it is a primary object of this invention to provide
new and improved apparatus for molding hollow bodies of liquid, heat cured
plastic. Another important object is to provide improved apparatus for molding
hollow bodies  of  from liquid heat cured plastic which  o  requires a minimum
expenditure of heat to form said bodies without the need for a large furnace and
conveying system. ST Other objects and advantages of this invention will become
apparent from the following specifications and claims which relate to the
drawings where: Fig. 1 is a

Sept. 4, 1958 Record of Conception of Inventions The following variations of the
Hula-Hoops which are sweeping the country are conceived: Ball dispensing hoops:
It is conceived to use the interior of the tubing comprising the hoop as a
storage volume for a plurality of small balls such as marbles, candy or ball gum
and to provide means for easily dispensing these balls thru an opening in the
wall of the hoop. This would serve several purposes (a) Multiple functions(1) If
the hoop is produced of transparent plastic, the balls may be seen from the
exterior as they roll around when the hoop is whirled thereby increasing the
visual attractiveness (2) means for storing and dispensing marbles and candy (3)
when filled will balls or marbles the hoop will be more difficult to twirl and
maintain on the body or arm than when empty The degree of skill required may
thus be varied by adding or removing marbles.

Automatic Fire Detection and Warning Apparatus: the following apparatus is
conceived for detecting and remotely indicating the presence of a fire (or other
phenomenon) and the location of the fire or other phenomenon. The apparatus may
be used to detect and remotely indicate at a monitor station or the like: (a)
Forrest fires (b) fires in buildings (c) The location of a specific change in an
environment or the proximity of an approaching or passing of a phenomenon,
person, vehicle or the like. The basic components of such a system are (a) A
detection transducer such as a photelectric cell, thermocouple, sound pick-up,
pressure or magnetically operated transducer or the like which is adapted to
become energize and generate an indicating voltage ~~ upon ~~ when a
predetermined physical or chemical change occurs in its environment (ref: 12 of
Fig. 1 next page) (b) A solar battery 10 adapted to provide power ~~ the ~~ for
the operation of the detection, if necessary, and/or a code generator and
transmitter 14. The generator and transmitter 14 is adapted to generate

which are remotely controlled by means of short wave signals. This is a
continuation in part of my copending application serial number , filed for
Facsimile Apparatus

The ~~ re ~~ monitoring of ~~ chan ~~ the condition of the environments of
plural locations situated remote from each other is frequently required for the
performance of such functions as fire surveylance in forrests or wooded ~~
alreas ~~ areas and the like. The present method of effecting said surveylance
is to provide look-out stations {{strikethroughand ~~ on high locations or in
the form of towers from which a man may survey the surrounding countryside for
visual indications of a fire. The report of a fire or of smoke is g ~~ effected
by the observer reporting directly by radio to a central station from which the
necessary fire fighting and control steps may be originated

and controlled. However, the system requires that numbers of human beings be
stationed at ~~ each ~~ the plural observation towers and they are frequently
endangered by forest fires.

It is accordingly a primary object of this invention to provide an improved
detection system for fires or other changing phenomena which requires a minimum
amount of human effort to effect the monitoring of the environments of a

Reference is made to the improved designs for protective and decorative adhesive
bandages shown on pages 36 to 40 of this notebook. I have just received a copy
of patent 2785677 (L. R. Stumpf) and have discovered that not only is the
structure and function of this patent different from the ideas and designs I
have presented but the claims of Stumpf do not read on my invention. I intend to
draw up a patent application on this invention and to include the following
embodiment therewith: Fig 6 Protection of the central area of the bandage is
effected by bonding a rectangular or disc shaped patch 32 of flexible or
semi-rigid plastic to the upper surface of the flexible J. B. Gilstein 12/20/59

plastic strip 12 above that portion thereof containing the gauze patch 18 which
is adhesively bonded to the other surface of 12. Holes H' extend thru the patch
32 in alignment with the holes H in strip 14. The material comprising 32 may
also be foamed plastic such as foamed vinyl or urethane, with the cells
extending to the surface 32' or closed off closed off on said surface ~~ 32' ~~
by fusion when the patch ~~ is ~~ 32 is shaped in a heated mold or die. The
patch 32 may be preshaped and ~~ adhesive ~~ bonded to the upper surface of 32
by means of an adhesive or may be heat sealed thereon. The patch may also be
molded from a liquid state directly on the upper surface 12' of 12 (ref my
pending pat app. entitled Molding Apparatus). The upper surface 32' of 32 may be
embossed or mold shaped with a decorative design such as a comic head, figure,
etc. It may also be decorated with a print or sprayed on colors. Jerome H

Record of Conception of Invention Oct 29-1958 Automatic Information Storage and
Reproduction System Reference is made to the commercially available COPYFLO
continuous printer manufactured by Haloid Xerox, Inc Rochester 3, N.Y. It is
conceived to utilize a machine such as the COPYFLO 24 on the like with certain
patentable modifications in the control thereof as a major component in an
automatic storage and printing system applicable to such functions as: (a) The
system utilized by the U.S. Patent Office for the filing of copies of patents
and the retrieval of said copies for individuals requesting them. Presently a
certain number of each copy is printed and stored. Copies are hand picked by one
or more of about two dozen office workers, collected and placed in envelopes

Aug. 15 1951 INTRODUCTION This notebook is intended ~~ to ~~ as a record of the
conceived inventions and progress in the development of electrical toys. The
inventor is completing a patent application, as this is written, on electrical
wheeled toys employing some of the basic manufacturing techniques to be
discussed in detail and utilized in the fabrication of the toy inventions to be
described. Many of the inventions to be listed and (or) sketched and described
in detail have already been recorded by individual sheets which have been
witnessed by the inventors brother and, mailed to record the date. In addition,

paper of his firm Mr. Alex Friedman and Mr. Levy, know, have known of my basic
vehicle invention since I first discussed it with ~~ them ~~ Richard Blum last

toy and proposed manufacturing techniques. Jerome Lemelson Aug 15-51 Witnessed

Aug. 15, 1951 Electrical Toys and Games Employing Printed, Stamped or Sprayed
Circuits. About nine months ago the author conceived of the possibility of
applying some of the present circuit application techniques to model toys and
games in combination preferably with electrical insulation materials such as
thermo-setting (plastic) JHL. and general plastic materials, paper, wood, etc.
These techniques involve printing, spraying, painting metals or metallic
materials which are capable of conducting an electric current to the
nonconducting surface of a game or toy. It is conceived that properly developed
manufacturing techniques for applying these conducting strips to toys would
enable their fabrication at a considerably lower cost than an item fabricated ~~
whi ~~with conducting elements such as wires (soldered), rods ~~ st~~. These
techniques could conceivably be applied to such items (to be described in
detail) as: (1) Toy vehicles and tracks (2) Toy vehicle games (utilizing a track
on a playing surface (3) Toy games utilizing circuits to create a variety of
electrically actuated effects. (4) General electrical toys.

August 15, 1951 Since I intend to file my first patent application in about a
week I am attempting to record most of my conceived ideas in this field at this
time Manufacturing Techniques and Devices: (1) Application of conducting element
by contact (printing or rolling). The conducting material may be a metal applied
in the molten state, a current conducting plastic applied as a liquid which
hardens upon cooling or sets after exposure to air, a powdered metal with a
bonding agent, etc. (A) Printing thru a porous plate: (Sintered metal, etc) (i)

PLASTIC FABRICATION PROCESSES & APPARATUS The following processes involve the
continuous extrusion of the thermoplastic materials such as polyethylene,
polypropylene, etc. into plastic sheet or film and its continuous vacuum drawing
into molds or containers for the purposes of (a) forming articles such CM
3/26/63 EL 3/30/63

as plastic bottles or tubes, (c) lining containers such as drums, cans, bottles,
paper, ~~or ~~corrugated or paperboard boxes. Methods & Apparatus include: I.
Continuously extrude or calender thermoplastic sheet, feed over or adjacent open
containers such as drums, boxes, cans, etc., clampingly engage the sheet against
the rim of the container and apply vacuum to the inside of the container (and/or
pressure above the sheet) while the sheet is semi-molten as the plastic sheet
being extruded and/or post heated, to draw the sheet into the container to form
a plastic liner, therefore which conforms to the shape of the container.
Containers are continuously fed on top of a belt conveyor or with the upper rim
of the container held by clamping means at the level of a belt or flight
conveyor parallel to the soft or semi-molten plastic sheet. Clamping of the
sheet against the rim may be effected by a second closed loop belt conveyor
disposed above the conveyor carrying the containers and above the sheet, or by a
flight of a closed loop flight conveyor. Vacuum may be applied to the inside of
each container to effect drawing the semi-molten sheet or film into the
container in one of several manners: viz(next page) CM 3/26/63 EL 3/30/63

pouches, of plastic film with a liquid to provide frozen ice pops, cubes, or

injector 3. The still connected filled pouch is next driven through a freezing
chamber preferably containing thermoelectric freezing elements in which it may
be detained until ready to be dispensed. W 4. Upon insertion of a coin into the
machine and operation of a flavor selector, the end (filled and frozen) pouch of
the strip of pouches is

are automatically dispensed into a reservoir to provide a quantity of the liquid
(fruit-bar) to be frozen, the need for supplying large quantities of the liquid

and provided with automatic valves and controls to effect mixing of the
concentrated fruit or sugar juice prior to filling pouches therewith B. Use of

first osculator system at both sender and receiver to which is operative to

write beam of the video receiver at the sending station at a first speed and a
second oscillator a beam sweep speed control means at both sending and receiving

Fluid Jet Devices Reference is made to fluid systems in which a small jet of
fluid such as air or other gas or liquid is used to control the direction of a
larger jet or stream of fluid from one path or passageway to another. The
following applications of such a system are conceived. I. Application to
electrical switching including circuit breaker applications. It is conceived to
generate a large flowing stream of fluid and utilize same to cool electrical
components of an operating electrical system by flow over and thru said
components. The stream is switchable to a passageway leading to one or more
cavities containing switch contacts or mechanical means for opening (or closing)
said contacts when fluid from said stream is diverted to said passageway leading
to said cavity or contact closing device. The ~~ div ~~ stream used to divert

Method of Molding A method of molding decorated articles is conceived in which a
sheet or film of decorated plastic (or metal) is pressure drawn into a cavity in
a mold or forced therein to conform to the shape of the cavity wall after which
(when the film is retained in position) molding material is injected or
otherwise admitted to the cavity of the mold and molded against the pressure
formed film or sheet (thermoformed or otherwise) to become integral therewith
during the molding process by fusing therewith or physically interlocking with
portions of the sheet so formed. Globe Structure A world globe is conceived
consisting of two shells each of which comprises a sphere assembled of
respective half shells, one inside the other. The inner shell is made of thin
vacuum formed plastic sheet with countries of the world printed on its outer
surface. The outer spherical shells is injection molded of two pieces and its
inside diameter is approximately the outside diameter of the inside shell.
Molded flanges of the outer shell halves snap together and retain flanges or
flange portions of the inner shell at the same time. 10-10-63 VM EJW 10/24/63
